This is a case for a variant of the quite wonderful universal transistor and component tester developed by Markus Frejek, and later Karl-Heinz Kübbeler. A full description of the project is available here: http://mikrocontroller.net/articles/AVR_Transistortester This case fits a kit sold by Banggood, see http://www.banggood.com/DIY-Meter-Tester-Kit-For-Capacitance-ESR-Inductance-Resistor-NPN-PNP-p-929603.html There is one version of the case bottom with holes for M3 countersunk screws. The other version is a pure snap lock, which I think works well enough. This version also has an internal structure that allows screws to be retrofitted. There are also two versions of the button; one with a collar that fits over the switch, and the alternative version with a flat bottom. Cases for variants with a larger graphical display are available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:797733 here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:694790 here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1580922 and here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1920077

Designed to be printed quite straightforwardly, without support and minimal cleanup needed. I used PLA.
The button may be printed in a contrasting colour, It needs your first layer to be set up accurately if you want to avoid cleanup. If your first line prints to wide, you will need to cut a bit internally to make it fit the button.
The standard version is entirely snap lock, so no extra hardware required. If you want to use screws, then it is best to use an M3 tap to create threads in the mounting holes of the top section.

title: Mini 12V LED downlight Kit (Now with Cable Hooks!!!)

description.text:
Like low power lighting?
Well we have a solution for you! This set of parts will allow you to construct small LED spotlight feature lighting, with adjustable brackets.
Included are some cable hooks as well to get you started. You will need:
5mm LED's (high intensity - whatever serves your needs best)
Some 3mm nuts and bolts (10 - 20mm)(2 per bracket)
Resistors (220 - 400 ohm, 390 preferred)
Hot Glue (or the next best thing you can find)
Soldering experience (or money enough to buy pre-wired LED's)
Figure Eight speaker wire or suitably insulated wire.
(check local electrical regulations - some countries are strict on this now)
8G X 19mm Square drive (self countersinking) screws - or similar. The resistors are for current limiting so you don't cook the LED's.
They should be in "series" with the LED, alternatively you can purchase pre-fabricated LED kits from Ebay or Jaycar dealers. The value of the resistor:
  • If lower: will increase power use and brightness, and shorten LED life
    • If greater: will reduce power use but decrease intensity, and increase LED life.
    • 330 and 390 ohm resistors are in the ISO "preferred ranges" and are readily available in 2% Metal film. I recommend 1/2 watt, as 1/4 watt may get too hot and melt the ABS. See attached images for suggested assembly methods. If you plan to run a heap of these, you will want to find an "LED Driver Circuit" on ebay. worth the investment. You are welcome to comment for advice and questions - however:
    WARNING!
    Use fuses or overload protection!
    I'm not liable for ignorance or mistakes!

title: Nexus 5 - Magnetic car mount with wireless charing

description.text:
This is a car mount for the Nexus 5. The mount is directly plugged into the cigarette lighter. It supports wireless charging (Qi) so you don´t need any cabels and can insert and remove the phone very quick. Because the charger has build in magnets the phone is well fixed.The phone itself is mounted into a case which fixes perfectly into the mount. Even when navigation is enabled (+bluethooth, +screen on, +wireless data) the phone is charged (this is often a problem because the Qi charger are not strong enough). If you want to build this item you only need:

  • Wireless charger:
    https://play.google.com/store/devices/details?id=nexus_wireless_charger

  • Car mount adapter for the cigarette lighter:
    http://www.amazon.de/dp/B00E4IWS5O/ref=pe_386171_37038021_TE_3p_M3T1_dp_1

  • Nexus 5 case:
    http://www.amazon.de/dp/B00FJJ38HY/ref=pe_386171_51767411_TE_M3T1_dp_2
    • All the parts have screws so you need only a T5 torx and a small Phillips screwdriver. The cabels are finally directly solderd on the PCB.

author: Maik0815

title: Prusa i3 X-axis lead screw upgrade

description.text: After dealing with inconsistencies and backlash with the belt drive design, we decided to give the lead screw a try. We started with the Y-axis for the trial, and moved onto this X-axis upgrade.

description.header: Y-axis lead screw upgrade is available here

description.text: Source files now available in Thing Files.

Notes:

  • All parts printed in ABS.

  • x-end right side.STL has in-file supports for the Z-stop. (There is an alternative file available with no z-stop.)

  • Top-Z-mounts and Bowden mount available for download in both 2 and 3-hole; uses standard Prusa frame hole dimensions. Mounts with the 625 bearing slots are available for threaded Z-rods that are approximately 300mm or greater in length.

  • X-carriage designed with a slightly larger 8mm smooth rod spacing (to accommodate the lead screw follower).

  • CREDIT: x-endstop holder.STL derived from ePoxi's Mechanical Y-EndStop holder for Prusa i3 (scad) here. Fantastic end stop to use. We recommend ePoxi's files for both X and Y axis end stops.

Updates:
  • Jan.19, 2015...deleted and re-uploaded all top z-mount STL files, renamed in easy to recognize left/right pairs due to so many variants in the downloads list.
  • Mar. 28, 2015...added Inventor files (.ipt) to download list.
  • Apr. 26, 2015...added tips under Instructions based on feedback.
  • Jul. 13, 2015...posted update, v2.0 lead screw upgrade

YouTube Video: Here is the printer in action For a closer look of the finished print (untouched): short imgur album Test print is the Deprime test object found here on thingiverse Running Repetier Host V1.0.6 and Slic3r V1.1.7
Natural ABS
.15mm first layer .2mm for the rest
30% first layer speed
45mm/sec perimeters, 70% outer perimeters
60mm/sec infill, 40mm/sec top layer infill
80mm/sec travel
25% honeycomb infill (just to show rapid changes in direction) Higher print speeds are possible but, so far, this seems to be the best balance for quality.
Check the Instructions tab for parts list and other important information regarding set-up.

Parts List: Main parts sourced from http://openbuildspartstore.com/.

  • Lead screw. 1000mm cut in half, save other half for Y-axis.

  • Nut Plate

  • Lock Collars 8mm I.D. x2

  • Coupler Fits Nema shaft and 8mm lead screw

  • 608 bearing or source at a local place like Fastenal for around a $1 each.

  • Zip ties If you don't already have some in the house, go buy a pack.

  • M4 bolt, nut and spring For z-stop. (optional)

  • M5 threaded rod Locally purchased (and cut) 1 meter long 5mm threaded rod for extending the z-height. Not necessary, but relatively inexpensive addition.

  • M3 nuts, bolts, and washers Everything is M3, except: optional Z-endstop and X-endstop (which use M2.5 or very small zip ties)

  • 625 bearing (optional Z-top stabilizer) or source at a local place.

Printing Notes:

  • Print both top and bottom Z mounts with the 8mm rod hole flat to the bed.

  • If printing a set of top Z mounts with the 625 bearing feature, be sure to generate basic supports; supports should pop right out and be a quick, easy clean up.

  • x-end right side.STL has in-file supports for the Z-stop. (There is an alternative file available with no z-stop.)

  • For the (optional) x-endstop: there was a slight bit of clearance issue with the lead screw (flat back of the x-endstop mount was touching tangent to the lead-screw), causing some minor surface friction. We fixed this by simply carving/filing out a shallow relief where the rub-point was.

  • 8mm smooth rod holes may be a bit tight/shallow. Easy fix for a custom fit is to bore it out with a drill bit (8mm / 5/16").

  • Be sure to print at higher infill % to maximize part rigidity.

Breaking in lead-screw follower: Use ample lubrication when breaking in the nut plate, it seems very hard to turn at first. Turn the axis, by hand, from home to full range and back several times before attempting to move with the stepper motor. Steps/mm: X-axis steps should be approximately 400 steps/mm if you are using 1/16th microsteps; 100 steps/mm if you are using 1/4th microsteps. Through experience, the lead screws require more torque. Reducing to 1/4 microsteps gives you the same resolution as belt drive, but you get more torque from the stepper to maintain speed/acceleration, in depth proof can be found here.. Suggest lowering max travel speed and acceleration if there is stalling.

comments.author: ssentein

comments.text:
The frame is initially elevated, but the posted feet will elevate the frame a bit more and slightly change the distance between the M8 threaded rods. Without referencing the exact dimensions from the rework it would be hard to tell you the exact change. The simplest way to determine if the parts will work for you, is to print 1 foot and measure overall height and relative distance from the table or flat surface to the Y axis rod, and compare to your current parts.
Printing 1 foot should take little more than an hour at the best quality settings and consume very little filament, but would give you a good comparison.

comments.text: I've upgraded my z and x to lead screws. My z is working fine. But my x is ratcheting. I've tried increasing the voltage to the max with no change. I tried swapping the y motor for the x as the y is the bigger 73oz/in motor. It doesn't even ratchet, but no movement either. I've tried plugging it into other axis drivers and swapped wires to make sure it's not my ramps board. Running the folgertech i3 2020. Any suggestions? [email protected]
comments.author: diablodel3

comments.text: Try reducing your microstepping on your ramps board. For example, if you're running at 1/16 microstep, pull one or two jumpers off to take it down to 1/8 or 1/4. You'll still have plenty of accuracy, but you'll gain back some precious torque from your motors. The motors will be louder, but better a bit noisier than stalling/skipping steps.  Try that and see if that helps.
comments.author: diablodel3

comments.text: Unfortunately it didn't help. I went as far as removing all the jumpers and maxing out the vreg. What i've come up with is that when I set the steps/mm to the proper number I lack either enough torque or the acceleration isn't high enough for it to move. If I set the steps/mm as though it were a belt it moves just fine, albeit an improper distance. I tried putting the bigger nema 17 with the 73oz/in torque and it didn't do anything. Any other suggestions? if it helps, i'm using a 8mm 4 start with brass nut, no backlash adjustment.

comments.text: Hi
comments.author: KenNg

comments.text:
Its difficult to give you a recommendation for acceleration settings without knowing anything about your printer.
If you use a brass follower, or delrin, or anti-backlash spring nut assembly, this will change acceleration results and
the "ringing effect" or rounded corners.
The size of your motors, and even the firmware and slicer will all determine how your settings effect your print quality.
Crisp, clean corners on a cube are a combination, of print speed, precise E-steps, acceleration, and jerk.
comments.author: KenNg

comments.text:
Are you using anti backlash on this?
I like your design.
comments.author: DeanR

comments.text:
We did not directly choose to utilize any anti-backlash components, but the delrin or acetal lead screw nuts from OpenBuilds naturally have anti-backlash characteristics.
When you tap or thread plastic the material compresses while being cut, causing the final thread dimension to be slightly smaller then the desired size. The lead screw nut, or follower, is very tight when initially installed and must be "bedded." This caused the material to form and wear to the shape of the threads.
During the moment power is no longer applied to the stepper motor, the natural tension of the bedded follower provides a braking effect to the axis, helping to limit backlash.
The enormous down side to this effect is that the axis requires more torque to accelerate and generates resistance during all movement.
Unfortunately we have not trialed any other type of follower to give feed back to alternate designs.
Hopefully this helps.
comments.author: DeanR

comments.author: Ghozt

comments.text: Agreed, all open loop systems will have some differential result from your desired outcome based on all other system factors. Lead screws show backlash because of the steppers limited magnetic attachment to the motor shaft. Higher speed, acceleration, and jerk will cause more backlash. We purposefully used the largest NEMA 17 stepper we found readily available, and switched to 1/4 microsteps to increase torque and limit backlash. ( http://openbuildspartstore.com/nema-17-stepper-motor/ ) We do not use any firmware backlash compensation, because the amount of backlash will change based in the print speed and intricacy of the model being printed. We have considered posting all of the .ipt files, due to multiple requests. The designs are still a work in progress and the printer is in the process of a large update for an enclosure. Look for .ipt files to be posted in the near future on both axis.
comments.author: Ghozt

comments.author: DeanR

comments.text:
In defense of the recording, my phone mic is a bit overly sensitive. It could have been fixed with some editing. The amount of noise produced by any printer is going to be directly related to the motor and the frame. The original kit that this prusa i3 started from was relatively cheap. The back plate and bed plate are thinner then normal ( < 3 mm). The motors are fairly large for a NEMA 17 (48 mm) and we are running 1/4 micro steps for increased torque. All of these factors add to an echoing mechanical vibration. The printer is a bit louder then the original design but nothing preventing you from being in the same room. We are currently in the early stages of a full openbeam frame with a full enclosure, while still using the basis of the prusa axis. Some thought has been put into testing 8mm frelon linear bearing sleeves, to assist in reducing vibration while maintaining tolerance at high speed. These can be found @ http://www.mcmaster.com/#standard-linear-bearings/=vs8xld
for anyone interested.

comments.author: bernard_de_nice

comments.text: We did put some consideration into repeated load change on the Z motor shafts. If you use the top Z supports which include a inset for a 625 bearing, you can capture the top of the Z rod above and below the bearing with M5 nuts and washers, this helps prevent the bouncing load change on the Z motors. This bouncing load has the biggest effect when you use Z lift/hop.  Some people believe capturing the Z rods will have a horizontal push/pull effect on the X axis if the Z rods are bowed. Short answer, yes it does, but the only movement you see is play in your bearings/bushings. Cheap bearings = lots of movement.  A bowed M5 threaded rod will not bow an 8mm shaft.  We look forward to seeing your version/additions.
comments.author: bernard_de_nice

title: Rubber band powered boat
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a very simple boat your kid (or even you) can play with in a pool or a bathtub.
Tape a rubber band to the shaft, wind it up, put the boat on the water and release it. You can print two boats to organize a race : the winner is the boat which goes the furthest ! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=egY8GBtH8CU&feature=youtu.be Also, if you're interrested, join my discord server to discuss about 3d printing, arduino, processing, ... and find many interresting electronic project ideas : https://discord.me/electronic_projects
Don't use a too powerful rubber band : the boat won't move faster, but simply sink and the water wheels may break.

I needed a linear table/macro slider and I was about to buy one when I realized that I could design and make my own.. Perhaps not that much cheaper but a lot more fun than buying one :)  
It's a simple design with not that many parts (see complete BOM under instructions) I wanted to use parts that are easy to get and that are inexpensive so i went with cheap China bearings/rails and ordinary threaded rod and el cheapo nuts and screws, all bought on eBay.  
You get 45mm of travel and each turn of the knob equals approx 0.8mm of movement. You can use a finer threaded rod and get even higer resolution but I think 0.8mm/turn is ok in most cases. It sure beats trying to move the tripod back and forth a few mm..  
The parts turn out quite good on my machine but there might be some fine trimming needed to fit the cover properly. The carriage and thread cover are designed to be printed standing up, but you are free to print them in any orientation you want :)

These brackets replace the magnetic catches that hold a shower door closed. The original sheet magnets will eventually corrode, de-laminate, and make a mess. The replacement brackets take Neodymium Disc Magnets (P.N. 58605K31 http://www.mcmaster.com/# ), and slip right in the extruded aluminum channel. Magnets are .250" dia x .1" thick,nickel plated. Magnets are a snug fit it the holes, but I will use a drop of c.a.. Make sure the poles are aligned such that they will attract when installed! I would have liked a little more holding force. Three magnets per side would have been better, but this is as good as the original. I'm not sure how this will hold up over time, but we'll see.

description.text: Oye! Oye! Brenda the articulated battle tardigrade has been released into the wilds of 3D printing! Join the Horde to be among the first humanoids to learn about the next epic project from Zheng Labs! We now return you to your regular model description.

Through some mighty confluence of geolocation and preferences algorithms my Facebook Trending feed indicated that the Green Bay Packers are currently obsessed with Settlers of Catan. Out-of-staters and internationals may be unaware that Wisconsin residents are legally obligated to be Green Bay Packers fans. My understanding is that late governor Robert "Fighting Bob" La Follete, sensing the future greatness of Packers football in the Badger State, slipped this requirement into the state constitution in 1902 after meeting the as-yet-unborn Vince Lombardi's mother in a Brooklyn pizzeria. We are nothing if not trendy and loyal to the green and gold here at Zheng Labs, and so we took a few hours off from publicizing our latest Kickstarter to create a 3D printable Packers-themed Robber that's compatible with Settlers of Catan.

title: Diamond Minecraft Tools -remix with keychain holes

description.text:
Minecraft tools (axe, pick-axe, sword, shovel) from http://www.thingiverse.com/CLB3122 which have been enhanced to just have keychain holes in the handles.
Read about this model at: http://www.mkrclub.com/2015/01/3d-printing-minecraft-tm-tools-as.html

I started with the great file from http://www.thingiverse.com/CLB3122 and imported into Autocad 123D Design.
I created a cylinder and overlapped it on the handle of each tool where I wanted to "punch out" a keychain hole, then used the Combine / Subtract tool to do that.
Very simple enhancement, but made it easier for kids to show off the sword, axe, pick-axe and shovel by connecting it to their backpacks!

description.text: Amazing by josh.wolf.powers [created with 3DTin]

I recently got myself a E3D v6 hotend, I do believe that is a nice hotend. but what I did notice was that the supplied groovemount was not that strong, it actually broke (though the nice people at e3d replaced it).  
Also the other groove mounts all needed some sort of friction, slide in action. That created wiggle. I made this one that can be fastened using 2 M3 hexbolts, leaving no room to wiggle whatsoever.  
The STL provided works perfectly for my E3D v6 3mm Direct feed.
Print out of ABS, PLA will deform when printing at higher temps.

description.text:
Omega headphone stand, voronoi style. Designed for larger headphones with earpads up to 11 cm.   
The STL I uploaded has a little bit thicker material than the picture I uploaded, because it was a little bit more flexible than I anticipated.  
(The headphones in the picture are Philips Fidelio X1)

You need a print bed of at least 20 cm. If your bed is smaller you could scale it, but no guarantees that your headphones will fit. To print this, you'll probably need to use some form of support, which can be hard to remove. Printed on my Zortrax M200 using these settings:
Material: Z-ABS, black
Layer height: 0,29 mm
Support: 10 degrees (20 degrees would probably have given a cleaner print, but that would have been a real pain to remove). I used support lite.
Total print time: a bit under 20 hours

comments.text: Made one for a friend on a Replicator 2.  Took a whopping 20+ hours of printing, but did it with supports.  Only did 15% infill, probably possible to do with NO infill, since it still seemed rigid enough at just 15% with 2 shells, and many sections were barely getting any internal support at all.  Had to scale it down a bit to fit the build area, but otherwise came out just fine.

description.text:
This is a mounting-case for a "Danfoss-Link" heating controller. The powersupply is meant to mount inside a flush-mounted box inside the wall.
As this was not possible here, i created this box, to mount the controller on the wall. Please read the Instructions carefully as this is not a perfectly engineered design.

First, there are two versions of this thing. Called width- and without-support. The difference is in the upper mounting holes. As they don't come out clean, i made a one-layer thin plate underneath the holes, as a support. This is the version "with-support".
If you want to use normal support-piles, choose the version without support. Assembly and Mounting

• Mount four M4-Nuts inside the upper holes. This works best if you screw in the bolt and nut alone (without the controller). The nut is drawn into the hole, and should stay there. Unscrew the bolt again.
  • All four nuts are fixed. If they dont stay, use a little bit of duct tape.
  • Now mount the box to the wall (using the lower four holes).
  • After that, pull the powercable through one of the side-holes, connect it to the rear-plate with the powersupply in it, and secure the plate using the four M4 bolts.
  • Now you can slide in the Link-Controller, and use your heating-control.
Made from natural ABS. Glue up parts by super glue.

description.text: They call it a bulkhead in the part catalog.  What the part actually is is the central part of the front suspension (for RWD vehicles).  The front arms connect to it, the front bumper goes on the bottom, and the flat plate of the chassis attaches to the angled part.  I've had a few break in the past from rough crashes and stuff.
You might have to ream the holes a bit, but it printed just fine by itself.    I recommend using a tough material, like nylon, but I bet it would work for a while in ABS or PLA.

description.text: Professor Bot and his team of makers have recently relocated to the Robolabs moon base to continue development of their unparalleled robot building technology away from the threat of the dangerous Dr. Warp. Disaster struck however when one of Dr. Warp's minions hacked into the RoboLabs mainframe and stole Professor Bot's Lunar Elite technology! This could prove catastrophic if the evil Dr. uses it to replicate a robot army. Professor Bot must now rely on Vertex, his finest creation to retrieve the plans for Lunar Elite before it's too late... UPDATE - I've uploaded a new version with completely redesigned joints which are much improved - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:69329

This is part of a university project, designing a posable 3D printed action figure for children. This particular design has been produced for the Develop3D 'Make a bot' competition. None of the parts will require support material to print.
The figure is comprised of snap-fit ball joints, most of the joints have been tested and although they may be very stiff at first they loosen up quickly. The joints work well printed in PLA at 0.1mm, 2 or 3 perimeters and a low infill like 5%.
Certain parts such as the upper leg are printed in two pieces. To avoid using support material they use a small extruded triangle to act as a friction fit. These are intentionally tight so the parts fit together securely. If they print too tight/loose you may want to sand or reprint them or just glue the parts if you want.
Deadlines are looming so I may not have the time to respond to requests that rapidly but I hope no-one has any problems printing it, the parts I've tested so far worked fine.  
I'm excited to see what colour combinations you come up with!
Update - it appears the original head file had some flipped normals so there is now a repaired file which should work

description.text: These pieces help with making wrap bracelets like those sold by Chan Luu.  They secure the leather and button to a standard 3/4" needlepoint frame making the weaving easier.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 or 0.3 layers with 0.4 nozzle worked for me.

Infill:

20-50

Notes: No support needed.

Print out one of each piece. Fill level or even layer height isn't that important. You may have to file out the grooves though to fit the leather cord. Measure out your leather cord and tie the button on it. Depending on the button size put it in the slot that fits best. The other piece will hold the leather. You'll probably have to secure both ends to the needlepoint frame with a little packing tape so it doesn't move around on you while you are working. You can find instructions all over the web for how to do the actual beading. An example is here http://www.instructables.com/id/Wrap-Bracelet/. My wife prefers beads with two sets of holes. Those are the ones you see in the photos. Update: added two versions that totally encircle the frame (name has wrap included). These actually print fine with no support on my printer with PLA. They are more stable and require less packing tape than the earlier versions. The dished out part is put a thumb tack through to hold onto the frame better.

description.text: A shelf that attaches to the holes in the interior wall of a Da Vinci 1.0, 1.0A, and 2.0 printer, to mount a webcam (or other accessory). Specifically, I am using the TeckNet C016 USB HD 720P Webcam, 5 MegaPixel, 5G Lens, USB Microphone & 6 LED (~$14, http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000Q3VECE ) because it has a close manual focus, and its own LED lights for when the Da Vinci's internal light turns itself off.

• Dimensions: 4.504"W x 1.250"D x 3.595"H (each)
  • Volume: 1.88 cubic inches
  • Weight: ~0.04 pounds

• Shelf: PTW-00-1-PT-0195 (Mount, Camera, DaVinci).STL
  • Prototype Shelf: PTW-00-1-PT-0195 (Mount, Camera, DaVinci) Proto1.STL - Small shelf to mount the camera in the corner, inside the rails, but my camera was too big to fit.
  • Prototype Shelf: PTW-00-1-PT-0195 (Mount, Camera, DaVinci) Proto2.STL - Vertical shelf, but I didn't want to mount the camera sideways ultimately.
• .STL names do not match .SLDPRT name because Da Vinci will not print file names over 56 characters.

• Print the shelf. Took ~2h:15m, and used 9.7m of filament. The settings I used are:
    A. Quality: Excellent
    B. Layer height: 0.20mm
    C. 3D density: High (50%)
    D. Supports: Yes
  • Carefully remove the supports from under the hooks. This is the only place they should have been created.
  • Test fit the shelf in your printer, in the front left corner, where the door opens. See picture for interior holes to use.
  • Test installation of your webcam.
  • Remove shelf, and secure webcam to the shelf with a cable tie, or other method.
  • Reinstall shelf. Nothing should touch the metal rails, since they spin.
  • Route wire, out door handle opening or side vent.
  • Adjust webcam positioning and focus.

title: Da Vinci Extruder Mounted Fan Duct

description.text:
This is a duct for PLA-style cooling fan to be mounted on the back of the extruder stepper. Takes a 50mm fan.  It directs the air under the stepper to point forwards towards the nozzle.  v001 hangs too low to use with the stock heated bed, because it crashes into the bed screws. Use v002 if your printer is using the stock bed. v001 would be better and allow more air flow if you happen to have a flush bed.  
It'll need some help printing the bridges. I had a fan inside my case and it did a great job.  Intended to be printed with the big flat side down.  
Right now it just kinda snaps on the back of the stepper motor, but I wasn't able to test it to see if that's secure enough. I honestly don't even know if this has any effect on the print. I'm just posting it here so other people can play with it.  
I ran the wires up with the rest of the extruder's wiring, and mounted a switch on the case to control it. Should be left off for first layers, and then turned on.  
All in all, it would definitely be better to make something that uses a centrifugal blower fan - something that has more pressure and can direct the air through a small duct like this better. But I had the 50mm axial fan on hand, so that's what I used.

title: Parametric Lego Mindstorms Mecanum Wheel 82 mm (iteration 2)

description.text:
Parametric Lego Mindstorms Mecanum Wheel 82 mm (iteration 2). The Mecanum Wheel can be printed without any support structures. Needed Parts for building a single wheel: 8x MecanumWheel_Roller 1x MecanumWheel2_Left (or MecanumWheel2_Right) 8x Lego Axle 5L (length=39.6 mm, PartNr 32073) Also added are the files with name containing the word "_printable". These files have been slightly modified so that my 3D printer prints them more accurately. The roller's profile has been generated based on following model:
http://www.chiefdelphi.com/media/papers/download/2749 Remark:
  • To build a four wheel robot one needs 2 left wheels and 2 right wheels. It is possible to drive sideways using these wheels
  • The current model is fully printed in PLA. It might be better to print the rollers in Ninjaflex or perhaps paint the PLA rollers with rubber paint to avoid slipping of the wheels.
  • Printing the base of the wheel in PLA is much easier then printing it in ABS. So I recommend using PLA for the base of the wheel.
    • Changes compared to previous design:
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:638687
  • the inner wheel is now hollow, requiring much less material to print it; it is therefor also much lighter
  • drawback is that the wheel can only be used from one side.
    • The production of the wheels:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xkOyJ76SO7k&feature=youtu.be The wheels in action:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2hp6FCNHvMw&feature=youtu.be For an alternative version (120 mm wheels) of this design see:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:681259 Almost perfect driving using printed Ninjaflex rollers:
    https://youtu.be/hm8kRz5gif0

comments.text:
We would like to make these wheels for our Lego robot. The first wheel has very tight holes and the pin does not fit in it. The axle hole in the middle is also very small - it is impossible to fit the axle in it. Is it intended or have we used wrong printer setting? Is it ok to drill it manually?
We have used PLA and the printable version of files.
comments.author: MirecXP

comments.text: The printable version of the STL have been created specially for my own Prusa i3 printer. The normal version of the files are the exact dimensions, which would be perfect to use if your printer prints exactly. So my recommendation would be to NOT use the "printable" version of the STL's, but use the normal ones. If your printer is not accurate you could consider using OpenSCAD to generate the STL's especially for your own printer. On the other hand, most of the time, the standard STL's will be good enough after some postprocessing work (drilling holes, milling the axle hole)
comments.author: MirecXP

description.text: Un boitier pour ranger les jetons du jeu de société Smallworld

This set of spur gears is intended as a training tool for spur gear theory.
  • large teeth to allow easier observation of tooth contact
  • two thread holes are provided to show that gear tooth contact follows the 20 degree pressure line from the intersection of the pitch diameters.
  • One face of the tooth follows one string, the opposite face follows the other string.
    • Fundamental gear parameters (in inches)
    diametral pitch (DP) = 3 inch
    number of gear teeth (N) = 12
    pressure angle (phi) = 20 degrees
    then using standard spur gear equations:
    pitch diameter (PD) = 4 inch
    outer diameter (OD) = 4.666... inch Note that the units above are provided in inches however the .stl files are provided in millimeters. references:

  • a .pdf from Boston Gear discussing both spur (& other) gear theory:
    http://www.bostongear.com/pdf/gear_theory.pdf

  • another .pdf providing additional information and clarification on both spur and spiral gears: "Parametric Design of a Spiral Gear Process" by Jeffery Baker, Jason Reynolds and Stephen Tecce of Worcester Polytechnic Institute:
    https://www.wpi.edu/Pubs/E-project/Available/E-project-042811-130543/unrestricted/Final_Report-Parametric_Design_of_a_Spiral_Gear_Process.pdf

print two of each part:
gear_4_DP3_N18_150116a.stl
gear_4_DP3_N18_150117_link.stl use care when gluing the parts together to avoid binding the gears.
  • see the link picture
  • place glue (I used acetone) only on top of the post and in the socket hole
  • assemble parts
  • insert string as shown in the gear assembly picture to show line of contact for teeth

It's a marker (non-directional) installed on the line used in cave diving.
For a directional marker look at my others creations.

title: Faraday Cage for blocking cellphone signals

description.text:
iVault is a 3D printable Faraday cage that can lock frequencies coming from your smartphone in order to protect your health and your privacy. It is designed to be air tight and impact resistant.   
You know how prolonged exposure to smartphone frequency can affect sleep patterns, produce attention deficit and even tumors?  
You know how the NSA use front and back doors in your smartphone to retrieve your location, real time vectorial data, and eavesdropping on you, your family, friends and associates through your handset GPS, microphones and cameras?  
Snowden has been labeled as "eccentric" due to a Hong Kong interview, where he insisted that a group of lawyers advising him in the Chinese territory “hide their cellphones in the refrigerator of the home where he was staying, to block any eavesdropping”, but it has nothing to do with temperature, “what you want to do is block the radio signals which could be used to transmit voice, data and block the frequency altogether” explained Adam Harvey, just as a Faraday cage would.   
Snowden lawyer, Anatoli Kucherena, recently declared that Edward does not use iPhone because it has programs that can be activated without the knowledge of its owner for retrieving sensitive data.   
For more information on assembling and an alternative download hub, please visit www.juguetesradiactivos.com

Download your free .stl printable file, import it to your 3D printing software and print a copy of ivault.stl file. (iVault is designed to be a single printed box)  
Choose and print the desired configuration, for iPhone4.stl, iPhone5.stl or neutral.stl holsters. (Holsters allow you to attach the cellphone to the ivault, the neutral holster is a flat top for generic smartphone use).  
Using aluminium foil, stack walls and cover the bottoms of both iVault hatches.  
Using acetone as glue (on ABS printing) attach the holsters to the iVault on the designated positions.  
Using household silicon for windows, create an air tight edge over the aluminium foil walls on both hatches.  
Remove excess plastic on latch with a cutter and brake it free.  
Enjoy!  
For a glossy finish on your ABS printed iVault, you can vapor wash it in acetone bath prior to assembly.

comments.text:
OMG, if you want to avoid any radiation you have to switch off your mobile completely!
Putting it in any kind of Faraday cage without switching it off will lead to higher radiation because your phone will try to connect to the next cell tower.

Baseplate to hold the FrSky Taranis in the Tarot TL-2876 Transmitter Tray.  
The Tarot transmitter tray holds the Taranis at a slight angle relative to the baseplate, which causes the bottom presser foot to push the bottom of the transmitter up and out of the tray. This baseplate interfaces between the spherical washer and the bottom of the transmitter, holding the transmitter firmly without requiring the spherical washer be glued to the Taranis.

Note that the back of the part is at an angle. The STL has been aligned to lie flat, if you regenerate the part from the SCAD file, don't forget to drop the part onto the bed! Also, because the tabs to engage the transmitter base plate slots (as well as the inset for the spherical washer) are elevated above the bed, printed support will likely be required.  
Printed at 0.127 layer height, 40% honeycomb infill, with support. Recommend a heated bed (I used 50C with PLA on blue painter's tape), as the size will cause warping at the corners.  
The spherical washer can be fitted into the relief by heating it to the plastic melting point and press fitting. It should bond to the plastic fairly well, and smooth any bridging problems with the inset hole. Recommend using a soldering iron to heat the washer and going slowly. If the washer falls out subsequently, a small drop of CA glue should hold it.

inspired by the book  
" Gedankenlesen durch Schneckenschreicheln"

This was designed in response to thingiverse item 538098. The original item did not provide any design source files and instead provided only a single STL file. This STL file turned out to be difficult to edit. Since the original was available commercially this wasn't surprising.  
However there are good reasons for wanting to be able to edit a design and one consisting entirely of text should be easy. This design provides a complete alternative and instructions for generating similar designs. In the spirit of open source, this current design is available to anyone without any kind of restriction.

THIS OBJECT
For this object you can simply slice the provided STL file and it should print well. I used 2.86mm diameter thermochromic PLA at 216 degrees on painters tape using an Ultimaker Original machine. I used CURA to generate the G-codes. Other settings were layer thickness 0.1mm and shell 0.8mm. (Thermochromic PLA changes colour depending on the temperature!) I have provided all the OPENSCAD source code as well. You simply need to copy all the *.SCAD files to a single directory and then open emc2.scad. You will be able to examine the code and see how it works. It is trivial to scale or move any of the elements. GENERAL FOR SIMILAR DESIGNS
Of course your designs may include other letters or you may even prefer a different font. Here is what you do. I used Linux Mint but these instruction will work on other operating systems as well. Firstly I downloaded a few interesting fonts from http://www.dafont.com/. You can find millions of fonts on the internet. The most difficult thing is finding something nice. I used one called "KeepOnTruckin". Or you could use one that is already available on your PC. To generate a basic graphic I use a program called INKSCAPE. This application outputs Scaleable Vector Graphics (SVG) files.
You will also need to add the paths2openscad extension available from the net or from thingiverse thing number 559139. The basic method is as follows:
Edit your page size to suitable dimensions. I used A7.
Select the text tool and place characters on your page one at a time at a suitable size in your chosen font. Then select each individual letter ONE-AT-A-TIME... • Click on Path -> Object to Path. (Inkscape doesn't confirm this operation). • Click on Extensions -> Generate from Path -> Paths to OpenSCAD. • Select a suitable output file name and save the generated OpenSCAD file. • Close the dialogue window. When you have done each letter (or group if you want to retain the layout) • Open the output files in OpenSCAD and view the result so far. In this case I wanted to move the letters so they overlapped. So I simply imported each letter into OPENSCAD and used the translate command to reposition it. See the OPENSCAD source files to understand exactly what I did.
Save your work regularly and press F5 to preview the result or F6 to compile the object for export as an STL. Then use your favourite slicing engine to generate the build file for your 3D printer. Simple!

title: Staender fuer AVM Fritz!Box 6490 / pedestal for AVM Fritz!Box 6490

description.text:
Staender fuer AVM Fritz!Box 6490 (!)
Fritz!Boxen werden gelegentlich recht warm.
Nicht jedes Moebelstück mag das, bei uns hat es schon mal einen Riss in der furnierten Oberflaeche deswegen gegeben.
Um solchen Aerger zukünftig zu vermeiden habe ich diese Erhoehung fuer unsere Box entworfen.
Das Ding ist hoechst simpel gehalten und laesst sich ruck zuck drucken. Damit die Box beim Staubwischen nicht immer von dem Ding runter rutscht kann sie zusaetzlich an den Staendern festgeschraubt werden.
(Muss aber nicht sein...)
Die Ständer werden, eigentlich klar, 2x benötigt...
Das Ding ist zwar für die 6490 entworfen koennte aber auch fuer andere Modelle passen. Falls nicht, laesst sich die .scad Datei einfach anpassen.
Ueber den Wert "ab" in der .scad Datei laesst sich der gewuenschte Abstand zur Oberflaeche einstellen.
Die Voreinstellung sind 10mm, das sollte in der Praxis auch locker reichen, der Wert kann aber natürlich beliebig gesetzt werden.
(Das Maximum wird nur durch die zur Verfuegung stehende Raumhoehe begrenzt...)
Fuer alles weitere bitte einen Blick in die .scad Datei werfen. Update: kleine Fehlerbehebung und Ergaenzung einer Option fuer Filamentsparer ;-)

description.text:
Simple stick-on arrow rest for recurve or low power bows. Tested and works well on a kids LIL'Banshee compound bow. If you want to see more and how I create prints and 3D designs like this check out my YouTube channel.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSHUc93NXGwBacoIDDqPU2w

I printed it with support everywhere to print a tower under the overhang and it printed well. I printed it very slow to give the short layer time cooling time to set. 20mm/s and a high infill but I don't think that matters as its mainly shells on the part that counts. stuck it on with some double sided tape and put about 10 arrows through it to test and it worked much better than shooting without it. I would be reluctant to use this on a higher weight bow.

comments.text: After flying my 200 qx in this frame for a while now, I can say it is far better than stock. You can put larger packs on it for extended flight times. This gives the 200 qx need weight to reduce the ballooning tendencies with the stock setup. Altitude is much easier to control during acceleration, as well as having the mass to carry that speed in flight. For now I have my fpv cam hot glued in place to test angles for the camera, but will be making a battery tray with integrated va1100 mount. Thank you soo much for this great design, my 200 qx has never flown as nice on stock frame.

Parametrizable leg supplement for the Dji Phantom 2. Just edit the Open Scad source file and fill in your needs: height, cable gap, tolerance. Please note that the piece is not simmetric, so look for the correct position when mounting it in the quadcopter.
Use M3 bolts of the apropriate lenght, and take care: there may be components under the nut.

The provided stl file is 10 mm height with a 1.5 mm gap to introduce the cables.
For other settings, the open scad file must be edited accordingly and the stl generated again. There is no special requirements to print it, so use your favourite settings.

Instead of coin collecting piggy bank I decided to design and print a coin holder for Euro currency. Added four different versions, each version has a different calculated (!) money capacity. Starting at 25 EUR, there is a 50 EUR, 75 EUR and 100 EUR version. Check out: http://youtu.be/_vjwDb5efZo Printable without support. Pictures and video show the 50 EUR version. 5 hr PLA print on Up Plus 2 (see video description for more info). Update #1: Added a version without 1 ct, 2 ct, 5 ct. (Requested by ioanniskar). Doubled 10 ct, 20 ct, 50 ct slots. Update #2: Added a 5 ct insert for the STLs published with the update #1 files. Thanks WeakNerve for the idea!

Turn the controler over. Loosen the 7 screw located at the bottom side of the HF-2. There is one screw hidden in the batt. compartment. Take out the two screws that hold the original D-pad.
Why? For me, I like to play sniper games. This button allows me to zoom in /out without activating other D-pad functions in the process.

title: Safe Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A small and handy safe box with a built in combination lock. The whole box prints preassembled (inspired by emmett) including hinges, the only thing to add are the combination lock dials and rods which easily slide into position. 
Two hexadecimal dials ensure a completely safe solution with 256 different possible keys (that is about as safe as WEP). Choose your own favourite key!

Print at fine resolution. Carefully push the two box halves to close the box until the hinge breaks free of any stuck plastic and moves freely. 
Print two dials and two rods and place one dial on each rod. The flat surface on the rod closest to the dial defines the lock open position - choose this to match your favourite code. There is actually a small 16-facet part of the rod (yes, very close to completely round) and this is where the dial should be (the inside of which is also 16-facet).
Do not forget the correct key. It will probably take you up to 60 seconds to retrieve it otherwise.

title: Ramps 1.4 box in OpenSCAD
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
New thing available, now with customizer support: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:861360
= A box for your ramps electronics. Fan holes are 60mm in diameter. Designed with OpenSCAD and fully customizable. Need extra length, width or hight to stuff more electronics in it? Need more fan holes, bigger or smaler? Edit the SCAD and your'e done. This box uses roughly 140g PLA (thanks to user Peterthinks) with standard wall thickness. Wall thickness is adjustable. I would suggest to mount the fan on the outside, blowing inwards. If the fan is mounted inside the box, cables might get stuck in the fan. The picture shows the +9mm box with Arduino, RAMPS 1.4 and LCD smart adapter. If you make this Thing i would like to see it! Upload a photo of your print with "I made One".
No support material needed! I suggest 40% infill. Wall_thickness should be at least 2*extrusion_width of you printer.

title: screw for a car wash mop

description.text:
One of the most important tools in a car wash is the mop. It's a mess if it's broke.
Especially, if only the screw between the shaft and the brushes breaks. One has to buy a complete new shaft, because this screw is not available separately. But if you have a 3D printer, you can reprint this screw :-) I redesigned it in openSCAD and printed it in blue PLA with a slice thickness of 0.2 mm to have a very clean shape.
The result is one of my best prints since I have my mendel - and best of all: It fits into the brushes on the one side and into the shaft on the other side. So, if anybody also possesses this kind of mop with a broken screw and - of course - a 3D printer: here is the design :-) You can read more about it on: www.ifeelbeta.de
print it, connect it to the shaft of your mop - and wash a car :-)

title: Cross Country Cactus
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a somewhat-accurate 1/24 scale model of a Citroën C4 Cactus, dressed up like it's ready to take on the Dakar, kinda like the Miata from last year. I tried staying a bit closer to the rules for T1 this year, except when I had ideas for things that would look cooler. (A race truck would have no reason to keep the rubber Airbump panels, but I thought it would be a cool application for flexible filaments)

There are 3 options for printing the body. You could just print the regular body; print the "airbump" version of the body in solid plastic, then the airbump panels separately, and squeeze them in; or print the "airbump" body and the "airbumpDual" file simultaneously if your printer handles dual extrusion well. These same options also apply to the wheels and tires, only there's no extra file needed as they are already centered for dualstrusion.
You'll also need to print 8 pins, 4 of those wheels and tires, 2 Left and 2 Right shocks, and 1 of each mudflap.
The body is the only part that should need to be printed with support.

description.text:
My 1st attempt at a bow serving tool. Not yet printed so untested, but how hard can it be. It has its own printable spindle but its probably going to be impossible to print without support and take forever with so hopefully std ones will fit but I have no reference for size to measure.
Similar posts in my group http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/3d-toys If you want to see more and how I create prints and 3D designs like this check out my YouTube channel.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSHUc93NXGwBacoIDDqPU2w
there are directional arrows on it to indicate which way to run the thread and then you can Google how to actually serve a bowstring. i will print this upright with the spool tabs at the top

comments.text: I'm by no means a expert I just designed what I saw online and printed it, mainly because the local archery shop made me feel like I'd better bring my own Vaseline next time, but I'd imagine so. its for keeping the strands of the bow string together making it easier to grip the string and to provide the nocking point where the arrow seats. it would easily wrap just about anything you need, the line I use is fly fishing backing (mainly because its what I had available) there are a few nice youtube videos on how to server the string ( ie start and end the covering) the grove may need to be bigger to cover larger diameters.

author: WillandMrData2

title: Knobs, based on: M3, M4, M5, M6, M8, M10 nuts and lock-nuts

description.text:
Knobs, based on: M3, M4, M5, M6, M8, M10 normal nuts and lock-nuts (they are a bit higher). After trying them I decided to make two versions of them: a loose fit (the nut can be pressed by hand in the knob) and a tight fit (the nut has to be pressed or hammered in the knob). The M4 knob is made for the CraftBot buildplate.
I have printed them with Kisslicer, 0.3mm layer height, 5 loops, 2mm skin thickness, 33% infill. They are designed to be printed without support structure. The knobs have little "snappers" at the bottom, to prevent the nuts to fall out , after hammering / drive them in the knob.
Scale / adjust the inset parameter of Kisslicer to fit your specific printer needs.

author: funbart

description.text: Keychain to hold a Cherry MX mechanical keyboard switch as a keychain. Made in Autodesk Inventor.

Parts required:
  • One of mxKeychain.stl
  • A ring or string
  • One Cherry MX keyswitch for plate mounting. (Mfr. Part # ends with 'N') Digikey has some
  • A Cherry MX Keycap
    • Directions:
  • Print with the large flat side on bottom. I used 100µm resolution on a Makerbot Replicator 2.
  • Cut off the leads of your Cherry MX switch.
  • Push the switch in. It's square; it doesn't matter which way you push it in. The fit is VERY snug, so it should fit in without any glue, but the hole for the post may require some carving out on the inside edge.
  • Add your keycap of choice and a ring or string, and attach it to your keys.

comments.text: If anyone needs cherry mx black keyswtches (2 wire and 4 wire versions) message me. I'm in USA

description.text:
This is a mount for the 2015 RoboRIO. The RoboRIO is attached to the mount via 4x 4-40 by 3/8 countersunk screws.   
This is a slight modification of the one that was printed by our team, as we had to drill out and widen the mount holes on out first print. If you print this let us know if we need to make the holes bigger or move them around.  
Printed at low quality on a makerbot replicator 2.
